items.title: 1.1.1 Make temporary preparations of cellular material suitable for viewing with a light microscope
content: **Procedure:**
1. Place a drop of water or mounting medium on a slide.
2. Collect a small sample of the material to be viewed.
3. Transfer the sample to the drop on the slide.
4. Gently lower a coverslip onto the sample.
5. Place the slide on the microscope stage.
6. Start with low magnification, then increase to observe cells.
7. Record your observations.
8. Clean the slide and coverslip after use.

items.title: 1.1.2 Draw cells from microscope slides and photomicrographs
content: **Drawing Steps:**
1. Observe cells, noting shapes and structures.
2. Lightly sketch cell outlines with a pencil.
3. Add details like organelles, using shading for contrast.
4. Label structures if identifiable.
5. Review and refine the drawing for accuracy.
6. Finalize by darkening lines and erasing guidelines.
7. Add annotations if necessary.
8. Repeat for other cells or structures.

items.title: 1.1.3 Calculate magnifications of images and actual sizes of specimens from drawings, photomicrographs and electron micrographs (scanning and transmission)
content: **Calculation Steps:**
1. Find the scale or magnification provided.
2. Use the formula: **Magnification = Image Size / Actual Size**.
3. If magnification is given, use **Actual Size = Image Size / Magnification**.
4. Ensure units are consistent (e.g., micrometers).
5. For electron micrographs, apply additional corrections if needed.
6. Verify your calculations.
7. Record and report your results.

items.title: 1.1.4 Use an eyepiece graticule and stage micrometer scale to make measurements and use the appropriate units, millimetre (mm), micrometre (μm) and nanometre (nm)
content: **1. Calibrate the Microscope:**

Place the stage micrometer on the stage and focus on the scale using the lowest magnification. Note the number of eyepiece graticule units that correspond to a known distance on the stage micrometer (e.g., 1 mm = 100 eyepiece units).
**2. Measure the Object:**
Place the object on the stage and focus on it. Use the eyepiece graticule to measure the size of the object in eyepiece units.
**3. Calculate the Size:**

Use the calibration factor to convert the eyepiece units to the appropriate units (mm, μm, or nm). For example, if 1 mm on the stage micrometer corresponds to 100 eyepiece units, and you measure 20 eyepiece units, the size of the object would be 0.2 mm.
**4. Use Correct Units:**
• For larger objects: use **millimeters (mm)**
• For smaller objects: use **micrometers (μm)**
• For very small objects: use **nanometers (nm)**
**5. Record and Report:**
Record your measurements and units accurately, and report them in your findings or reports.

items.title: 1.1.5 Define resolution and magnification and explain the differences between these terms, with reference to light microscopy and electron microscopy
content: **Resolution:**
Ability to distinguish two points as separate. Limited by wavelength.
**Magnification:**
Enlargement ratio of image to actual size. Achieved with lenses.
**Light Microscopy:**
Resolution limited by visible light wavelength (400-700 nm).
**Electron Microscopy:**
Higher resolution due to shorter electron wavelength (0.005 nm).

content.section: 1.2 Cells as the basic units of living organisms

items.title: 1.2.1 Recognise organelles and other cell structures found in eukaryotic cells and outline their structures and functions, limited to:
content: **1. Cell Surface Membrane**
• **Structure:** Phospholipid bilayer with embedded proteins and cholesterol molecules.
• **Function:** Regulates the movement of substances in and out of the cell; provides cell-cell recognition and communication; maintains cell integrity and shape.
**2. Nucleus, Nuclear Envelope and Nucleolus**
**Nucleus:**
• **Structure:** Surrounded by a double membrane called the nuclear envelope, which has nuclear pores for transport.
• **Function:** Contains genetic material (DNA) and controls cell activities such as growth, metabolism, and reproduction.
**Nuclear Envelope:**
• **Structure:** Double membrane with nuclear pores.
• **Function:** Regulates the movement of materials between the nucleus and cytoplasm.
**Nucleolus:**
• **Structure:** Dense region within the nucleus.
• **Function:** Site of ribosome assembly.
**3. Rough Endoplasmic Reticulum**
• **Structure:** Network of membrane-bound sacs and tubules with ribosomes attached to its surface.
• **Function:** Involved in protein synthesis, folding, and transport; plays a role in the synthesis of membrane proteins and proteins destined for secretion.
**4. Smooth Endoplasmic Reticulum**
• **Structure:** Network of membrane-bound tubules and vesicles lacking ribosomes on its surface.
• **Function:** Synthesizes lipids, including steroids
**5. Golgi Body (Golgi Apparatus or Golgi Complex)**
• **Structure:** Stack of flattened membrane-bound sacs (cisternae).
• **Function:** Modifies, sorts, and packages proteins and lipids from the endoplasmic reticulum for transport to other parts of the cell or for secretion outside the cell.
**6. Mitochondria (including the presence of small circular DNA)**
• **Structure:** Double membrane structure with inner folds called cristae; contains small circular DNA molecules.
• **Function:** Site of cellular respiration, where ATP (energy) is produced through aerobic metabolism.
**7. Ribosomes (80S in the cytoplasm and 70S in chloroplasts and mitochondria)**
• **Structure:** Made of ribosomal RNA (rRNA) and protein; two subunits: large (50S in prokaryotes, 60S in eukaryotes) and small (30S in prokaryotes, 40S in eukaryotes).
• **Function:** Protein synthesis; 80S in the cytoplasm (composed of 60S and 40S subunits in eukaryotes), 70S in chloroplasts and mitochondria (composed of 50S and 30S subunits).
**8. Lysosomes**
• **Structure:** Membrane-bound vesicles containing digestive enzymes.
• **Function:** Breaks down and recycles cellular waste, foreign substances, and damaged organelles.
**9. Centrioles and Microtubules**
**Centrioles:**
• **Structure:** Pair of cylindrical structures composed of microtubules
• **Function:** Organize the microtubules of the cytoskeleton during cell division and form the bases of cilia and flagella.
**Microtubules:**
• **Structure:** Hollow tubes made of tubulin protein subunits arranged in a cylindrical shape.

• **Function:** Provide structural support for the cell, serve as tracks for intracellular transport, and are involved in cell division (forming the mitotic spindle) and cellular movement (cilia and flagella).
**Cilia:**
• **Structure:** Hair-like structures protruding from the cell surface, composed of microtubule bundles.
• **Function:** Beat in a coordinated fashion to move fluid, mucus, or other substances across the cell surface; also used for sensory functions in some cells.
**Microvilli:**
• **Structure:** Small, finger-like projections of the cell membrane containing actin filaments.
• **Function:** Increase the surface area of the cell membrane to aid in absorption and secretion; commonly found in cells involved in absorption, such as intestinal and kidney tubule cells.
**10. Chloroplasts (including the presence of small circular DNA)**
• **Structure:** Double membrane organelles containing chlorophyll; internal membranes called thylakoids are stacked into grana.
• **Function:** Site of photosynthesis, where light energy is converted into chemical energy (glucose); contains small circular DNA molecules.
**11. Cell Wall**
• **Structure:** Rigid, outer layer made of cellulose (plants), chitin (fungi), or peptidoglycan (bacteria).
• **Function:** Provides structural support and protection; helps maintain cell shape; prevents excess water uptake.
**12. Plasmodesmata**
• **Structure:** Channels that traverse the cell walls of plant cells, connecting the cytoplasm of adjacent cells.
• **Function:** Facilitate communication and transport of molecules between plant cells, allowing for the exchange of nutrients, signaling molecules, and other substances.
**13. Large Permanent Vacuole and Tonoplast of Plant Cells**
**Vacuole:** Membrane-bound organelle containing cell sap (mostly water, enzymes, and ions).
**Tonoplast:** Membrane surrounding the vacuole, separating its contents from the cytoplasm.
• **Function:** Stores water, sugars, ions, pigments, and waste products; maintains turgor pressure; facilitates plant growth and development.

items.title: 1.2.2 Describe and interpret photomicrographs, electron micrographs and drawings of typical plant and animal cells
content: **Key Features to Identify:**
**1. Cell Shape and Size:**
• Plant cells: generally rectangular with a rigid cell wall
• Animal cells: more rounded without a cell wall
**2. Cellular Structures:**
• **Animal cells:** nucleus, mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum (ER), Golgi apparatus, lysosomes
• **Plant cells:** chloroplasts and a large central vacuole (in addition to animal cell structures)
**3. Nucleus:**
• Prominent nucleus in the center of the cell, surrounded by a nuclear envelope
• Contains genetic material (chromatin) and a nucleolus
**4. Cytoplasm:**
• Appears granular and contains various organelles
**5. Endoplasmic Reticulum:**
• **Rough ER (RER):** presence of ribosomes on its surface
• **Smooth ER (SER):** lacks ribosomes and appears smoother
**6. Golgi Apparatus:**
• Stack of flattened membrane-bound sacs (cisternae) near the nucleus
• Involved in processing and packaging proteins and lipids
**7. Mitochondria:**
• Elongated structures with inner folded membranes (cristae)
• Responsible for energy production (ATP synthesis)
**8. Lysosomes (in animal cells):**
• Membrane-bound vesicles containing digestive enzymes
• Involved in breaking down waste materials
**9. Chloroplasts and Large Vacuole (in plant cells):**
• **Chloroplasts:** containing chlorophyll for photosynthesis
• **Large central vacuole:** for storage and turgor pressure maintenance
**10. Cell Membrane:**
• Outer boundary of the cell (plasma membrane)
• Regulates the movement of substances in and out of the cell

items.title: 1.2.3 Compare the structure of typical plant and animal cells
content: **Same Aspects:**
• Both have a cell membrane, nucleus, mitochondria, endoplasmic reticulum, Golgi apparatus, and cytoplasm.
• Both use ribosomes for protein synthesis.
• Both store genetic material in the nucleus.
**Different Aspects:**
• **Cell Wall:** Plant cells have a cell wall made of cellulose, while animal cells do not.
• **Chloroplasts:** Plant cells have chloroplasts for photosynthesis, which are absent in animal cells.
• **Vacuoles:** Plant cells have a large central vacuole for storage and support, while animal cells have smaller vacuoles or none.
• **Plasmodesmata:** Plant cells have plasmodesmata for cell-cell communication, which are absent in animal cells.
• **Lysosomes:** Animal cells have lysosomes for intracellular digestion, while plant cells have fewer lysosomes or none.

items.title: 1.2.4 State that cells use ATP from respiration for energy-requiring processes
content: **ATP (Adenosine Triphosphate):**
Cells use ATP from respiration for energy-requiring processes such as:
• Active transport
• Protein synthesis
• Muscle contraction
• Cell division
• Nerve impulse transmission

items.title: 1.2.5 Outline key structural features of a prokaryotic cell as found in a typical bacterium, including:
content: **Key Structural Features of Prokaryotic Cells:**
**1. Unicellular**
• Prokaryotic cells, such as those found in bacteria, are single-celled organisms.
**2. Generally 1–5 μm diameter**
• Size: Prokaryotic cells typically range from 1 to 5 μm in diameter.
**3. Peptidoglycan Cell Walls**
• A structural feature of bacterial cells, peptidoglycan is a polymer consisting of sugars and amino acids
• Forms a mesh-like layer outside the cell membrane, providing structural support and protection.
**4. Circular DNA**
• Prokaryotic cells, including bacteria, have a single, circular DNA molecule located in the nucleoid region
• Contains the genetic information essential for the cell's function and reproduction.
**5. 70S Ribosomes**
• Prokaryotic cells contain ribosomes that are smaller (70S) compared to eukaryotic cells (80S)
• Ribosomes are the cellular machinery responsible for protein synthesis.
**6. Absence of Organelles Surrounded by Double Membranes**
• Unlike eukaryotic cells, prokaryotic cells lack membrane-bound organelles such as mitochondria, chloroplasts, and nuclei.

items.title: 1.2.6 Compare the structure of a prokaryotic cell as found in a typical bacterium with the structures of typical eukaryotic cells in plants and animals
content: **Same Aspects:**
• Both have a plasma membrane that regulates the passage of substances in and out of the cell.
• Both contain ribosomes for protein synthesis.
• Both have genetic material (DNA) that carries the instructions for cellular functions.
**Different Aspects:**
• **Nucleus:** Eukaryotic cells have a nucleus, while prokaryotic cells have a nucleoid region.
• **Membrane-bound organelles:** Eukaryotic cells have membrane-bound organelles, such as mitochondria and endoplasmic reticulum, while prokaryotic cells do not.
• **Cell wall composition:** Eukaryotic cells (in plants) have a cell wall made of cellulose, while prokaryotic cells have a cell wall made of peptidoglycan.
• **Cell division:** Eukaryotic cells undergo mitosis or meiosis for cell division, while prokaryotic cells undergo binary fission.
• **Size and complexity:** Eukaryotic cells are generally larger and more complex than prokaryotic cells.

items.title: 1.2.7 State that all viruses are non-cellular structures with a nucleic acid core (either DNA or RNA) and a capsid made of protein, and that some viruses have an outer envelope made of phospholipids
content: **Virus Structure:**
**1. Nucleic Acid Core:**
• All viruses consist of genetic material, either **DNA or RNA**
• Contains the instructions for making new virus particles
**2. Protein Capsid:**
• Genetic material is surrounded by a protein coat called a **capsid**
• Protects the genetic material and helps the virus infect host cells
**3. Outer Envelope (some viruses):**
• Some viruses have an additional outer envelope
• Made of phospholipids derived from the host cell membrane
• Contains viral proteins that help the virus attach to and enter host cells
